greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Irregular triangle read by rows: row n gives exponents in prime factorization of n.
comment: Lengths of the runs are given by A061395(n),n>=2: [1,2,1,3,2,4,1,2,... ].
This sequence contains every finite sequence of nonnegative integers. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Jun 22 2005
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Rows n = 1..250 of triangle, flattened
example: ... and reading the exponents gives the sequence.
Since for example 99=2^0*3^2*5^0*7^0*11^1, we use this symbol for ninety-nine: 99: {0,2,0,0,1}. Concatenating all the symbols for 1,2,3,4,5,6,..., we get the sequence.
mathematica: f[n_] := If[n == 1, {0}, Function[f, ReplacePart[Table[0, {PrimePi[f[[-1, 1]]]}], #] &@ Map[PrimePi@ First@ # -> Last@ # &, f]]@ FactorInteger@ n]; Array[f, 29] // Flatten (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Mar 08 2019 *)
program: a067255_row n = f n a000040_list where
g v e = if m == 0 then g v' (e + 1) else e : f v ps
xref: Cf. A001222, which gives the row sums of this table.
Cf. A054841, rows reversed and concatenated into a decimal number.
results.author: _Jeppe Stig Nielsen_, Feb 20 2002
